definition: to steal away/to beat it
to slip away/to escape in stealth/to skate
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
lucky/giga- (meaning billion or 10^9)
surname Ji/abbr. for Jilin Province 吉林省[Ji2 lin2 Sheng3]

sentences.english: Change your life, get the fear out of here.
sentences.chinese: 改變你的生活，讓恐懼溜之大吉。

sentences.english: They scarpered when the police got involved.
sentences.chinese: 當警方介入時，他們便溜之大吉。

sentences.english: When the police arrived, the burglars took a powder over the back wall.
sentences.chinese: 警察趕到時，夜賊早已翻後牆溜之大吉了。

sentences.english: They always seem to slip away right when you need them most.
sentences.chinese: 它們似乎經常在你最需要它們的時候溜之大吉。

sentences.english: When a healthy rat smells a cat, it flees.
sentences.chinese: 當一隻健康的老鼠聞到貓的味道時，立馬溜之大吉。

sentences.english: It's a good time for you to slip away.
sentences.chinese: 這正是你溜之大吉的好時機。

sentences.english: I looked back to see my "loot" when talking to me beat a hasty retreat.
sentences.chinese: 我回頭一看，我的“戰利品”趁我說話時溜之大吉了。

sentences.english: I think I'll be out of here entirely in a couple of years.
sentences.chinese: 我想，兩年裏我會徹底溜之大吉”。

sentences.english: The door was open. He could make a dash for it down the hall.
sentences.chinese: 門是開着的，他可以穿過門廳向大門衝去，溜之大吉。

sentences.english: That person looked budda to win, to sneak away, the wc on find an excuse.
sentences.chinese: 那人一看佛祖贏了，向溜之大吉，便藉故上wc。

sentences.english: At that time, I was about to squeeze near the bus door and planned to slip away when the bus reached the stop.
sentences.chinese: 我已經快擠到車門邊，準備車一停靠，就溜之大吉。

sentences.english: He was really planning to slip out and away.
sentences.chinese: 實際上，他是在打算溜之大吉。

sentences.english: When they could not pay their debts, they skipped out between twodays.
sentences.chinese: 當他們無法償還債務，他們會兩天之內溜之大吉。

definition: to leave in stealth/to slip away
to escape without trace (idiom); to make one's getaway (from the scene of a crime)/to show a clean pair of heels
(coll.) to beat it/to take French leave
to run away/to escape
see 一哄而散[yi1 hong1 er2 san4]
to take to one's heels/to scram
to escape/to flee/to run away
to run away/to take to one's heels
(dialect) to rush off/to scamper off double-quick/to take to one's heels/to make oneself scarce
to flee in defeat/to bolt
to vanish/to be nowhere to be found/unfounded (story)
to break into a run
lit. scatter like birds and beasts (idiom)/fig. to head off in various directions/to flee helter-skelter
like a wisp of smoke/(to disappear etc) in an instant
to turn on one's heels/to walk away abruptly
to get away/to escape (from obligations)/to free oneself/to disengage
